articles.title: ECMAScript Safe Assignment Operator Proposal
articles.description: We often feature ECMAScript proposals that are in their later stages, but how about a brand new one you could get involved with? This one proposes an interesting additional bit of language syntax (?=) that returns a [error, value] tuple from an assignment.
articles.author: Arthur Fiorette

articles.title: Crafting a 13KB Game: The Story of Space Huggers
articles.description: We always love Frank‚Äôs dives into how he produces neat JavaScript experiments and, in this case, a complete game in just 13KB ‚Äî and if it inspires you, the latest js13kGames game development competition has just started.
articles.author: Frank Force

articles.title: Google's Angular Lead Sees Convergence in JavaScript Frameworks
articles.description: ‚ÄúWhen picking a framework, don‚Äôt overthink it. It will end up being the same technology anyway with a different facade.‚Äù Minko Gechev talks about leading the way in converging Google‚Äôs Angular and Wiz frameworks.
articles.author: Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

articles.title: Announcing Official Puppeteer Support for Firefox
articles.description: As of version 23, Google‚Äôs originally Chrome-only Puppeteer browser automation library now has first-class support for Firefox too.
articles.author: Mozilla Hacks

articles.title: Patterns for Memory Efficient DOM Manipulation
articles.description: Marc shares a solid look at the best practices to employ in order to avoid excess memory usage when managing/updating the DOM, all with a hope to make your apps faster. A good overview of the core principles behind DOM manipulation and optimization.
articles.author: Marc Grabanski

articles.title: 'How I Won $2,750 using JavaScript, AI, and a Can of WD-40'
articles.description: This is far from a technical JavaScript article, but it‚Äôs a fun story, involves some code and statistics, and ultimately might make you laugh.
articles.author: Dave Kiss

articles.title: Common Causes of Memory Leaks in JavaScript
articles.description: Filled with basic examples oriented around V8-based runtimes like Node.js and Deno.
articles.author: Trevor Indrek Lasn

articles.title: Learn Web Components
articles.description: If you‚Äôre looking to scrub on your Web Components know-how, this road map should prove useful. It‚Äôs a collection of good third party articles covering a wide range of knowledge.
articles.author: Andrico Karoulla

articles.title: A Tale of Evading JavaScript Anti-Debugging Techniques
articles.description: When debugging code written by a third party, there could be some traps thrown in your way to prevent your usual debugging techniques. What to do? Revisiting a popular article from 2023.
articles.author: Veritas

articles.title: Fine-Grained Reactivity in Svelte 5
articles.description: Taking a close look at Svelte‚Äôs new so-called fine-grained reactivity.
articles.author: Adam Rackis

articles.title: Volta 2.0: Install and Run JavaScript Tools Quickly
articles.description: A long-standing Rust powered tool for installing and switching JavaScript related tools (like Node, TypeScript, Yarn, etc.) ‚Ä¶ ‚Äúno matter the package manager, Node runtime, or OS.‚Äù GitHub repo.
articles.author: Volta

articles.title: Floating UI: Positioning for Tooltips, Popovers, Dropdowns, etc.
articles.description: A library to create ‚Äòfloating‚Äô elements such as tooltips, popovers, and dropdowns. Essentially a next-gen Popper which it now officially succeeds.
articles.author: atomiks

articles.title: React Figma: Use Components as a Source for Figma Designs
articles.description: A lot of folks use Figma to mock up designs for their React components, but what about the other way around? Use React components as a source for your designs in Figma! GitHub repo.
articles.author: Ilya Lesik

articles.description: ‚≠ê If you've wondered why so many new npm packages are spam these days, it may be because of 'Tea'. Though not the drinking kind..
Brendan Eich has expressed his support for the currently stage 1 Decimal draft proposal for bringing a more precise decimal number representation to JavaScript.
There's an early technical preview of React Native WebGPU. William Candillon shows it off in ‚ñ∂Ô∏è this 9-minute screencast.
jQuery UI 1.14.0 ‚Äì The legacy effects and widgets library reduces support for older browsers.
Madge 8.0 ‚Äì Create graphs of module dependencies.
React Native 0.75, Angular 18.2, Bun 1.1.23, ESLint 9.9

articles.title: Relative Color Syntax ‚Äî Some Basic Use Cases
articles.description: We now have broad support for the relative color syntax. Chris Coyier takes a look a this ‚Äúextremely powerful way to manipulate colors in CSS‚Äù in relation to colors you're already using.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: The Puppeteer Browser Control Library Announces Official Firefox¬†Support
articles.description: As of version 23, the Puppeteer browser automation library now has first-class support for Firefox.
articles.author: Mozilla Hacks

articles.title: How Google Handles JavaScript In Its Indexing Process
articles.description: At one point if you wanted Google to index your content it needed to be directly in the HTML and not dynamically rendered with JavaScript. Things have since changed of course , but how much?
articles.author: Zecchini, Moore, Siddle, Ubl (Vercel)

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Start Over-Engineering Your CSS
articles.description: An interesting talk from the recent CSS Day conference about purposely going ‚Äúover the top and embracing complexity‚Äù as a way to deepen our understanding of CSS.
articles.author: Kevin Powell

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Japanese Web Design: Weird, But It Works. Here's Why
articles.description: ‚Äúbeneath the overwhelming user interface lies undeniable psychology‚Äù.
articles.author: Phoebe Yu

articles.title: HTML Web Components Can Have a Little Shadow DOM, As A Treat
articles.description: Scott notes that some of the current discourse around Web Components ‚Äútends to conflate a couple of things‚Äù, chiefly around augmenting HTML via custom elements and how the Shadow DOM comes into play.
articles.author: Scott Jehl

articles.title: font-size Limbo
articles.description: Some nuanced thoughts on what font-size we should be reaching for as a default in 2024. Geoff Graham at CSS-Tricks chimed in too.
articles.author: Sebastian Laube

articles.title: The Anchor Element
articles.description: An informative look at the humble HTML <a> anchor element, explaining what it is, how it works at the browser level, and how to use it correctly. Heydon has also taken a look at the abbr element, and the address element.
articles.author: Heydon Pickering

articles.title: The Dying Web
articles.description: A plea to us all to give Firefox a try, because open standards and privacy are ‚Äúmore important than a few milliseconds of loading time‚Äù.
articles.author: Matthias Endler opinion

articles.title: typlr.app: Create Fonts in the Browser
articles.description: If you‚Äôve never attempted to make your own font, this might be a cool place to start! This interactive tool allows you to customize each letter‚Äôs shape and kerning, and you can install it as a PWA.
articles.author: Evgeny Agasyants

articles.title: ObsoHTML: Node and CLI Tool to Find Obsolete HTML
articles.description: ObsoHTML is a Node.js script designed to scan HTML, PHP, JavaScript, and TypeScript files within a specified directory for obsolete or proprietary HTML attributes and elements. Should help keep things tidy.
articles.author: Jens Oliver Meiert

articles.title: tailwindcss-highlights: A Tailwind Plugin to Add Highlights to Text
articles.description: The term ‚Äúhighlights‚Äù here refers to an effect similar to a highlighter pen for marking up an actual paper document. Includes 20 variants of the effect, which you can see here.
articles.author: Julian

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Inter 4.0: A Big Font Update for UI Design
articles.description: Now with true italics, optical sizing changes, and stylistic alternatives. However, this version 4.0 update doesn‚Äôt appear to be on Google Fonts yet.
articles.author: Oliver Sch√∂ndorfer

articles.title: Slab: A Programmable Markup Language That Simplifies The Creation of HTML
articles.description: An alternative to tools like Pug, claiming to offer advantages like improved readability, built-in programming constructs, integration with JSON data, and an easy learning curve.
articles.author: V√µ Minh Thu
